elements.content: The supramolecular interactions of classical O−H···O hydrogen bonding and aromatic π−π stacking found in the crystal structure of isophthalic acid are retained, with minor modifications, in the structures of its complexes with lithium, sodium, rubidium, and cesium, where stacked hydrogen-bonded ribbons of partially deprotonated isophthalate anions are combined with alkali metal ion coordination. The coordination number increases as expected with cation size, from irregular tetrahedral for Li+, through a mixture of octahedral, trigonal prismatic, and irregular pentacoordinated for Na+, to cubic for Rb+ and Cs+. The arrangement of metal ions around the anions also varies considerably in these structures, despite the relative constancy of the arrangement of anions among themselves. The supramolecular properties of the acid thus have potential for design purposes in complexes of this type.
elements.clean_text: The supramolecular interactions of classical O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding and aromatic π-π stacking found in the crystal structure of isophthalic acid are retained, with minor modifications, in the structures of its complexes with lithium, sodium, rubidium, and cesium, where stacked hydrogen-bonded ribbons of partially deprotonated isophthalate anions are combined with alkali metal ion coordination. The coordination number increases as expected with cation size, from irregular tetrahedral for Li+, through a mixture of octahedral, trigonal prismatic, and irregular pentacoordinated for Na+, to cubic for Rb+ and Cs+. The arrangement of metal ions around the anions also varies considerably in these structures, despite the relative constancy of the arrangement of anions among themselves. The supramolecular properties of the acid thus have potential for design purposes in complexes of this type.

elements.content: Alkali metal complexes of isophthalic acid display supramolecular interactions (hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking) remarkably similar to those in the crystal structure of the acid itself, demonstrating their structure-directing capabilities in the presence of much stronger ionic interactions that have little or no geometric and directional preferences.
elements.clean_text: Alkali metal complexes of isophthalic acid display supramolecular interactions (hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking) remarkably similar to those in the crystal structure of the acid itself, demonstrating their structure-directing capabilities in the presence of much stronger ionic interactions that have little or no geometric and directional preferences.

elements.content: The structural chemistry of isophthalic acid (H2ip, benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid) has been much less investigated than that of its 1,2 (phthalic acid, H2p) and 1,4 (terephthalic acid, H2tp) isomers, with respect to both the parent acids themselves in pure form or in molecular adducts, and their singly or doubly deprotonated anions in salts and metal coordination complexes, as demonstrated by a search of the Cambridge Structural Database (version 5.29 with one update, January 2008). In the case of alkaline earth salts or complexes containing no other metals, 13 structures have been reported for H2p and 11 for H2tp, but only 1 for H2ip (not including duplicate structures); the corresponding numbers for alkali metal salts or complexes are 18 for H2p and 8 for H2tp, but none at all for H2ip. We have undertaken an investigation of salts and complexes of H2ip with main-group and transition metals, and report here our results for the alkali metals. The lack of any strong coordination geometry preference for these metal ions, the predominantly ionic nature of interactions between them and oxygen-donor ligands, and the variation of metal ion radii enable us to assess the extent to which the main structural features of H2ip itself are maintained as structure-directing principles in the complexes and how these influences are modified by the interactions with the metal ions and, in some cases, solvent molecules present.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The structural chemistry of isophthalic acid (H2ip, benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid) has been much less investigated than that of its 1,2 (phthalic acid, H2p) and 1,4 (terephthalic acid, H2tp) isomers, with respect to both the parent acids themselves in pure form or in molecular adducts, and their singly or doubly deprotonated anions in salts and metal coordination complexes, as demonstrated by a search of the Cambridge Structural Database (version 5.29 with one update, January 2008). In the case of alkaline earth salts or complexes containing no other metals, 13 structures have been reported for H2p and 11 for H2tp, but only 1 for H2ip (not including duplicate structures); the corresponding numbers for alkali metal salts or complexes are 18 for H2p and 8 for H2tp, but none at all for H2ip. We have undertaken an investigation of salts and complexes of H2ip with main-group and transition metals, and report here our results for the alkali metals. The lack of any strong coordination geometry preference for these metal ions, the predominantly ionic nature of interactions between them and oxygen-donor ligands, and the variation of metal ion radii enable us to assess the extent to which the main structural features of H2ip itself are maintained as structure-directing principles in the complexes and how these influences are modified by the interactions with the metal ions and, in some cases, solvent molecules present.

elements.content: The crystal structure of H2ip itself, determined at room temperature, has been reported twice, with no significant differences. We use here the later, more precise structure for comparison purposes. Its main features are the occurrence of typical centrosymmetric pairs of O−H···O hydrogen bonds linking two carboxylic acid groups of adjacent molecules and resulting in an essentially planar zigzag ribbon of molecules, and the stacking of these ribbons above each other with a characteristic lateral offset of the rings as a result of π−π interactions, the perpendicular interplanar spacing being 3.371 Å and the centroid−centroid distance for the rings being 3.758 Å. The repeat unit of the hydrogen-bonded ribbon of molecules has a length equal to that of the monoclinic unit cell b axis, 16.364(6) Å. Weak C−H···O interactions link approximately coplanar adjacent parallel ribbons, with H···O distances of 2.66 and 2.69 Å. These dimensions characterizing the principal hydrogen-bonding and π-stacking interactions of crystalline H2ip are found to occur with a reasonable degree of reproducibility in the crystal structures of the alkali metal complexes of the acid reported here, with some modification arising from the partial deprotonation and the incorporation of alkali metal cations in the structure.

Infrared spectra were measured on a Nicolet 20-PCIR FT machine. Microanalysis was performed by the Newcastle University Chemical and Materials Analysis service.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All chemicals were commercially obtained and were used as supplied. Methanol, obtained as reagent grade from Aldrich, was not dried prior to use. Infrared spectra were measured on a Nicolet 20-PCIR FT machine. Microanalysis was performed by the Newcastle University Chemical and Materials Analysis service.

elements.content: LiI (150 mg, 1.12 mmol) and H2ip (160 mg, 0.96 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (10 mL). After one day, the resulting mixture was filtered to remove a small amount of precipitate, and pyridine (0.1 mL, 1.24 mmol) was added to the solution. Slow evaporation of the solvent in air over two months led to single crystals of the product, which were separated by filtration. Anal.: C, 55.73; H, 2.93%. Calcd for C8H5LiO4: C, 55.84; H, 2.91%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Li(Hip), 1 

LiI (150 mg, 1.12 mmol) and H2ip (160 mg, 0.96 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (10 mL). After one day, the resulting mixture was filtered to remove a small amount of precipitate, and pyridine (0.1 mL, 1.24 mmol) was added to the solution. Slow evaporation of the solvent in air over two months led to single crystals of the product, which were separated by filtration. Anal.: C, 55.73; H, 2.93%. Calcd for C8H5LiO4: C, 55.84; H, 2.91%.

elements.content: NaI (101 mg, 0.67 mmol), H2ip (89 mg, 0.53 mmol), and 1,8-bis(dimethylaminonaphthalene) (DMAN, 144 mg, 0.67 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (10 mL) with heating and stirring. After being cooled, precipitated (HDMAN)I was removed by filtration and the solution was allowed to evaporate slowly, giving further (HDMAN)I and the desired product, which was recovered by filtration and separated manually as single crystals. Anal.: C, 44.29; H, 3.62%. Calcd for C8H5NaO4·1.25H2O: C, 45.61; H, 3.56%. These results, together with an observed 1.50% for N, are consistent with contamination of the product with a small amount of (HDMAN)I.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Na(Hip)⋅1.25H2O, 2 

NaI (101 mg, 0.67 mmol), H2ip (89 mg, 0.53 mmol), and 1,8-bis(dimethylaminonaphthalene) (DMAN, 144 mg, 0.67 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (10 mL) with heating and stirring. After being cooled, precipitated (HDMAN)I was removed by filtration and the solution was allowed to evaporate slowly, giving further (HDMAN)I and the desired product, which was recovered by filtration and separated manually as single crystals. Anal.: C, 44.29; H, 3.62%. Calcd for C8H5NaO4⋅1.25H2O: C, 45.61; H, 3.56%. These results, together with an observed 1.50% for N, are consistent with contamination of the product with a small amount of (HDMAN)I.

elements.content:
Despite several attempts, it was not possible to obtain suitable crystals of a potassium complex of H2ip for structure determination, even with recourse to synchrotron radiation.

X-ray Crystallography

Data were measured at 150 or 160 K on Nonius KappaCCD (1−3) and Bruker SMART 1K (4) diffractometers with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Crystal data and other information are given in Table . H atoms attached to C atoms were constrained as riding, with C−H = 0.95 Å and U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C); those attached to O atoms were refined with O−H restrained to 0.97 (1) Å (the value obtained by free refinement in the case of 1, and appropriately rather longer for these hydrogen-bonded systems than the frequently constrained value of 0.84 Å) and U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(O). H atoms were not located on the water molecules of 2; the positions of some of them can be inferred from hydrogen-bonding considerations, but most of them appear not to participate in hydrogen bonds and it is possible that they are disordered. The assigned position of one acid H atom in 3 (where it was constrained to ideal geometry) and in 4 (where it was restrained as in the other structures) leads to an asymmetric O−H···O hydrogen bond in which the H atom is disordered over two equivalent positions close to an inversion center; there is a slight preference for this situation in 4 when the atom is refined freely, but the alternative of a precisely symmetric hydrogen bond, with H ordered on the inversion center, gives almost identical R factors and related indicators, and can not be ruled out. This is discussed in the results section below. No other disorder was found in the structures. A small degree of twinning was detected and approximately treated for 2 and 3; these two structures are less precise than the others. The largest residual electron density peaks are close to the metal ions in 2−4. Standard programs were used: Bruker SMART and SAINT and Nonius COLLECT and EvalCCD for data collection and processing; SHELXTL for structure solution, refinement and graphics; and SHELXTL together with PLATON and local software for results interpretation and preparation for publication.

All the complexes were obtained by treatment of H2ip with the corresponding metal iodide and a nitrogen base as a deprotonating agent. In all cases, the nitrogen base and methanol are not incorporated in the structures, which contain only metal ions, Hip− anions, H2ip, and (in the case of 2) water molecules. The degree of deprotonation of the acid seems to be related to the hardness of the metal cation, rather than to the amount of base used; this was varied in numerous repeated experiments, and the amounts reported here are those that led to the successful generation of crystalline products.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

All the complexes were obtained by treatment of H2ip with the corresponding metal iodide and a nitrogen base as a deprotonating agent. In all cases, the nitrogen base and methanol are not incorporated in the structures, which contain only metal ions, Hip- anions, H2ip, and (in the case of 2) water molecules. The degree of deprotonation of the acid seems to be related to the hardness of the metal cation, rather than to the amount of base used; this was varied in numerous repeated experiments, and the amounts reported here are those that led to the successful generation of crystalline products.

elements.content:
Concerning the structures, we consider first the metal ion coordination by the ligands and then the ways in which these structures are related to each other and to the structure of H2ip.

The asymmetric unit of the crystal structure of 1 [Li(Hip)] contains only one Li+ cation and one Hip− anion (Figure ). Each cation is coordinated by O atoms of four different anions, and each anion coordinates four different cations; one O atom of the anion bridges two cations, and the protonated O atom remains uncoordinated, so that this carboxyl group is involved in the coordination of only one cation, whereas the deprotonated carboxylate group is associated with three cations. The coordination geometry of Li+ is distorted tetrahedral, as is commonly observed for this cation, the main distortion being the small O−Li−O angle of 90.15(14) Å in the discrete centrosymmetric Li2O2 ring formed by two bridging O atoms and two cations; Li−O distances span the relatively small range 1.923(3)−1.990(4) Å (Table ).

The asymmetric unit of the crystal structure of 2 [Na(Hip)·1.25H2O] is much more complex, encompassing four Na+ cations, four Hip− anions, and five coordinated water molecules (Figure ). The surroundings of the four cations are quite different (Tables and ). Na(1) has a distorted octahedral environment defined by O atoms of six different anions; two of these O atoms belong to carboxyl OH groups, whereas the other four serve as bridges between pairs of symmetry-equivalent cations, forming centrosymmetric Na2O2 rings that are linked together in a ribbon. Na(2) is also six-coordinate, but with trigonal prismatic geometry, being surrounded by O atoms of three different anions and three water molecules. One of the water molecules bridges two symmetry-equivalent cations. Na(3) has somewhat distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by O atoms of four different anions and two mutually trans water molecules. Two of these anion O atoms and one water molecule act as triple bridges between Na(3) and Na(4), which is only five-coordinate; the geometry is irregular and involves also a further anion and a terminal water molecule in the other two sites. Of the four crystallographically independent anions, one coordinates three cations, one coordinates five, and the other two coordinate four each. Two of the five water molecules are bridging ligands, whereas the other three are terminal. Coordination numbers of five and six are common for Na+, which displays considerable flexibility in its coordination geometry.

3 [Rb(Hip)(H2ip)] and 4 [Cs(Hip)(H2ip)] are isostructural, and only the more precise structure of 4 is considered here; the same comments apply to 3. The asymmetric unit contains one Cs+ cation lying on an inversion center so that it formally counts only one-half, and one H2ip molecule, one acid H atom of which either lies on an inversion center or is disordered over two sites close to the inversion center, generating an (Hip···H···ipH)− or (Hip−H···ipH−) anionic hydrogen-bonded assembly with a symmetric or asymmetric hydrogen bond, half of this singly charged assembly lying in the asymmetric unit to balance the cation charge (Figure , Table ). The unique Cs+ cation is eight-coordinate, its surrounding O atoms forming a cube with little distortion. All of these O atoms serve as bridges between pairs of cations, in such a way that the CsO8 cubes share pairs of opposite faces and are linked together in a chain along the short unit cell a axis. The unique average “H1.5ip1.5−” ligand in the asymmetric unit coordinates four cations, and these are all at the “half-deprotonated” end of the ligand, where each of the two O atoms bridges two cations; the other end of the ligand, which has an ordered carboxylic acid group, takes no part in metal coordination, forming instead the familiar carboxylic acid dimer motif through a pair of O−H···O hydrogen bonds around an inversion center. The concentration of the coordinating behavior of the ligand at one end means that this partially deprotonated carboxyl(ate) group serves as a short bridge linking adjacent chains of CsO8 cubes to give a two-dimensional arrangement for the overall coordination of cations by the ligands, in which an exactly planar layer of cations is sandwiched between two sheets of ligands, as shown in Figure . This two-dimensional coordination network is in contrast to the three-dimensional networks found in the structures of 1 and 2, where both ends of each ligand are involved in coordination to cations.

elements.content: Taken as a series, the four structures display the expected increase in coordination number for the increasing cation size on descending the group of alkali metals. The irregularity of the coordination geometry in some of the structures, and the variation found in the structure of the sodium complex 2, reflect the lack of a geometrical preference for these metals, complexes of which are generally regarded as predominantly ionic rather than involving significant covalent coordination bonding. Considerable flexibility is also found in the arrangement of cations around the formally coordinating oxygen atoms, relative to the C−O bonds.

elements.content: This flexibility arising from a lack of any strong coordination geometry preferences allows supramolecular interactions of H2ip and Hip− to exert a significant influence on the crystal structures of the complexes, even though these interactions are much weaker than the dominant ionic interactions between the metal cations and organic anions, and we turn now to a comparison of these features of the structures with the corresponding characteristics of the known crystal structure of H2ip itself.

elements.content: If we consider the hydrogen bonding pattern in 4 and 3, we find the formation of polymeric chains shown in Figure b, which can be compared with those in Figure a for H2ip. The parent acid has pairs of O−H···O hydrogen bonds between carboxyl groups arranged around approximate (noncrystallographic) inversion centers, with an R 2 2(8) motif: two donors and two acceptors in an eight-membered ring. The 1,3-substitution of the carboxyl groups gives the hydrogen-bonded chain a zigzag shape. The arrangement for 4 is very similar; one of the two R 2 2(8) ring motifs is retained, this time with precise crystallographic inversion symmetry, involving the carboxyl groups of adjacent Hip− anions, while the other is replaced by a single O−H···O hydrogen bond together with coordination to two Cs+ cations, one on each side of the hydrogen bond, across another inversion center. The O···O distance is 2.476(6) Å (Table ), a little shorter than that for the conventionally paired hydrogen bonds [2.616(5) Å]. The hydrogen bonding thus generates again a zigzag chain. It runs along the unit cell bc diagonal [011], with a repeat unit length of 17.471 Å, slightly longer than that of H2ip at 16.364 Å, the small extension being the result of the lateral slippage of the carboxyl and carboxylate groups involved in the single hydrogen bond compared with two carboxyl groups with a pair of hydrogen bonds (see Figure ). Although we have modeled the single hydrogen bond as disordered and asymmetric, because this is closer to the result obtained by unconstrained refinement of the H atom and for consistency with the treatment in all of the structures reported here, it could also be ordered and symmetric, with the H atom on the inversion center, as is found for some short and strong hydrogen bonds. This does not, however, affect the main conclusions of this work significantly. It should be noted that the diffraction data were measured at low temperature, which tends to favor asymmetric hydrogen bonds, as is shown by variable-temperature neutron diffraction studies of carboxylic acids and related systems. Refinement of the structure of 4 from a room-temperature X-ray data set indicates a move of the paired hydrogen bonds toward a more symmetric arrangement, in accordance with this (full details are not presented here). We also note that the infrared spectra of 3 and 4, measured at room temperature, display sharp bands at 1683, 1608, and 1582 cm−1 for 3 and at 1682, 1608, and 1580 cm−1 for 4, which are characteristic of symmetric hydrogen bonds in carboxylic acid dimers.

elements.content: Formation of ribbons by hydrogen bonding of H2ip and its anions in the crystal structures of (a) the acid and (b) 4, (c) 1, and (d) 2.
elements.clean_text: 5  Formation of ribbons by hydrogen bonding of H2ip and its anions in the crystal structures of (a) the acid and (b) 4, (c) 1, and (d) 2.

elements.content: In the case of 1, where the anion has only one full carboxyl group (compared with two in H2ip and an average of 1.5 in 4), single O−H···O hydrogen bonds are formed, giving a polymeric chain (Figure c), rather than pairs of hydrogen bonds in discrete dimers. There is no inversion symmetry relating adjacent hydrogen-bonded anions, and the carboxyl and carboxylate groups are directly opposite each other (as in centrosymmetric R 2 2(8) motifs, but with one longer O···O separation having no intervening H atom) rather than laterally displaced as in 4. The zigzag chain thus has a repeat unit length of 16.019 Å (the unit cell b axis), very similar to that of H2ip and rather shorter than that of 4; the asymmetry of the carboxy−carboxylate interaction increases the degree of bending of the zigzag, shortening the repeat unit slightly.

elements.content: Although the structure of 2 is rather more complex, having four independent cations and four Hip− anions (together with five water molecules) in the crystallographic asymmetric unit, zigzag chains of hydrogen-bonded anions can still be identified in the structure (Figure d). There are two different chains, parallel to each other, each involving two of the anions of the asymmetric unit, and both have essentially the same arrangement. Along each chain, the hydrogen bonds alternately have no associated Na+ cations or are associated with two cations in the same way as the single hydrogen bonds in the chain of 4. Each hydrogen bond is a single O−H···O interaction, and the hydrogen bonds with no associated cations have a conformation that can be described as syn-anti in contrast to the syn-syn arrangement required for two carboxyl groups with a pair of hydrogen bonds and found also in 1. This different arrangement reduces the length of the repeat unit of the chain, which is here 15.962 Å, the unit cell a axis length.

elements.content: Although the details of the hydrogen bonding are different in these various structures, in each case it produces zigzag chains of molecules/anions, the repeat unit length of which is largely dictated by the rigid geometry of the H2ip or Hip− framework and only secondarily affected by the number and precise conformation of the individual hydrogen bonds and the presence of coordinated cations.

elements.content: The other dominant supramolecular interaction in the crystal structure of H2ip is offset π−π stacking of the aromatic rings, which are parallel with a perpendicular interplanar spacing of 3.371 Å and a ring centroid-centroid distance of 3.758 Å (equal to the unit cell a axis length). This stacking, for just two molecules, is shown in Figure a. The corresponding arrangement for stacked anionic units in 4 is shown in Figure b, and the resemblance is striking. Here too the adjacent units are strictly parallel, with a centroid−centroid distance of 3.875 Å (the unit cell a axis length once again) and a perpendicular interplanar spacing of 3.435 Å. Such effective stacking is not achieved in the structure of 1; Figure c shows the arrangement of two almost parallel anions, which have a dihedral angle of 5.5° (0 for parallel planes), an approximate interplanar spacing of 3.22 Å, but a centroid-centroid separation of 4.542 Å, a lateral displacement too great to indicate any significant genuine stacking interaction. In this case, the main supramolecular interactions of H2ip can not be maintained together with the incorporation of coordinated Li+ cations. However, perhaps somewhat surprisingly, effective stacking is found in the complex structure of 2. In this case, the anions of one hydrogen-bonded chain stack above and below those of the inversion-generated equivalent of the other chain, and vice versa; this arrangement for the four independent anions is shown in Figure d (two of the anions have been transformed by inversion symmetry from the arrangement seen in Figure d). In the stack thus formed by two of the anions, the dihedral angle between adjacent anions is 0.5°, interplanar spacings are alternately 3.331 and 3.365 Å, and centroid−centroid distances are alternately 3.757 and 3.718 Å; in the other stack, the corresponding values are 2.0°, 3.336 and 3.336 Å, 3.733 and 3.741 Å. These dimensions are remarkably similar to those in H2ip and 4.

In the stack thus formed by two of the anions, the dihedral angle between adjacent anions is 0.5°, interplanar spacings are alternately 3.331 and 3.365 Å, and centroid-centroid distances are alternately 3.757 and 3.718 Å; in the other stack, the corresponding values are 2.0°, 3.336 and 3.336 Å, 3.733 and 3.741 Å. These dimensions are remarkably similar to those in H2ip and 4.

elements.content: Stacking of molecules/anions in adjacent ribbons in the structures of (a) H2ip, (b) 4, (c) 1, and (d) 2. In each case, the view is normal to the mean plane of a ribbon of molecules/anions.
elements.clean_text: 6  Stacking of molecules/anions in adjacent ribbons in the structures of (a) H2ip, (b) 4, (c) 1, and (d) 2. In each case, the view is normal to the mean plane of a ribbon of molecules/anions.

elements.content: In addition to the O−H···O hydrogen bonding within chains and the aromatic π−π interactions forming stacks of chains in H2ip, there are weak C−H...O hydrogen bonds linking adjacent chains laterally, with H···O distances of 2.66 and 2.69 Å. Similar in-plane C−H···O interactions are found in the alkali metal complexes, with H···O distances in the range 2.47−2.91 Å.
elements.clean_text: In addition to the O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding within chains and the aromatic π-π interactions forming stacks of chains in H2ip, there are weak C-H...O hydrogen bonds linking adjacent chains laterally, with H⋅⋅⋅O distances of 2.66 and 2.69 Å. Similar in-plane C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions are found in the alkali metal complexes, with H⋅⋅⋅O distances in the range 2.47-2.91 Å.

elements.content: The supramolecular interactions of classical O−H···O hydrogen bonding and atomatic ring π−π stacking play a significant structure-directing role in the crystal structures of alkali metal complexes of isophthalic acid, as they do in the structure of the parent acid itself; a zigzag chain of hydrogen-bonded acid molecules/anions is present in all of these structures, and parallel stacking of the chains above each other is a feature in almost all of them. These interactions give very similar dimensions in the appropriate repeat unit distances of the structures and hence in some of the unit cell parameters. Coordination of the alkali metal cations is achieved without major disruption of these supramolecular interactions of the acid, despite the range in cation size and coordination number and the much greater strength of the ionic interactions between the metal cations and the organic anions, because these ionic interactions have little or no directional or other geometric preference. Such supramolecular interactions thus have potential for design purposes in crystal structures of compounds of this type, in which metal ion coordination geometry preferences are not strong.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The supramolecular interactions of classical O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding and atomatic ring π-π stacking play a significant structure-directing role in the crystal structures of alkali metal complexes of isophthalic acid, as they do in the structure of the parent acid itself; a zigzag chain of hydrogen-bonded acid molecules/anions is present in all of these structures, and parallel stacking of the chains above each other is a feature in almost all of them. These interactions give very similar dimensions in the appropriate repeat unit distances of the structures and hence in some of the unit cell parameters. Coordination of the alkali metal cations is achieved without major disruption of these supramolecular interactions of the acid, despite the range in cation size and coordination number and the much greater strength of the ionic interactions between the metal cations and the organic anions, because these ionic interactions have little or no directional or other geometric preference. Such supramolecular interactions thus have potential for design purposes in crystal structures of compounds of this type, in which metal ion coordination geometry preferences are not strong.

cln_elements.content:
LiI (150 mg, 1.12 mmol) and H2ip (160 mg, 0.96 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (10 mL). After one day, the resulting mixture was filtered to remove a small amount of precipitate, and pyridine (0.1 mL, 1.24 mmol) was added to the solution. Slow evaporation of the solvent in air over two months led to single crystals of the product, which were separated by filtration. Anal.: C, 55.73; H, 2.93%. Calcd for C8H5LiO4: C, 55.84; H, 2.91%.

Synthesis of Na(Hip)·1.25H<sub>2</sub>O, <bold>2</bold>

NaI (101 mg, 0.67 mmol), H2ip (89 mg, 0.53 mmol), and 1,8-bis(dimethylaminonaphthalene) (DMAN, 144 mg, 0.67 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (10 mL) with heating and stirring. After being cooled, precipitated (HDMAN)I was removed by filtration and the solution was allowed to evaporate slowly, giving further (HDMAN)I and the desired product, which was recovered by filtration and separated manually as single crystals. Anal.: C, 44.29; H, 3.62%. Calcd for C8H5NaO4·1.25H2O: C, 45.61; H, 3.56%. These results, together with an observed 1.50% for N, are consistent with contamination of the product with a small amount of (HDMAN)I.

Synthesis of Rb(Hip)(H<sub>2</sub>ip), <bold>3</bold>

RbI (102 mg, 0.48 mmol) and H2ip (81 mg, 0.49 mol) were dissolved in methanol (10 mL), and pyridine (0.5 mL, 6.20 mmol) was added. Slow evaporation over a period of 1 week gave single crystals of the product. Anal.: C, 45.85; H, 2.50%. Calcd for C16H11O8Rb: C, 46.11; H, 2.64%.

Synthesis of Cs(Hip)(H<sub>2</sub>ip), <bold>4</bold>

CsI (66 mg, 0.25 mmol) and H2ip (126 mg, 0.76 mol) were dissolved in methanol (10 mL), and pyridine (1 mL, 12.40 mmol) was added. Slow evaporation over a period of 3 weeks gave single crystals of the product. Anal.: C, 41.61; H, 2.44%. Calcd for C16H11CsO8: C, 41.40; H, 2.37%.
